name: ubenimex
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1447
Reason: The core structure of ubenimex can be considered to be benzoic acid, which has a melting point of around 122 degrees Celsius. The modifications to consider include: an isobutyl group, an alpha-amino group, a secondary amine connected to an aromatic ring, an amide group, and a hydroxyl group. The isobutyl group (+30) will raise the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions. The alpha-amino group (+10) will contribute to hydrogen-bonding capabilities, raising the melting point, but less so than a primary amino group due to steric hindrance. The secondary amine connected to an aromatic ring (+5) will have a slight increase in molecular weight and some limited hydrogen-bonding potential. The amide group (+40) is a strong site for hydrogen bonding, significantly raising the melting point. Finally, the hydroxyl group (+20) introduces an additional strong site for hydrogen bonding. The effects of these functional groups are considered additive.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. 
- The presence of the urea group (NC(=O)C(O)) typically increases the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and resonance stabilization, which can be estimated to add approximately +80°C. 
- The presence of the amide group (C(O)N) can also increase the melting point due to hydrogen bonding and resonance stabilization, contributing an estimated +50°C. 
- The presence of the tertiary butyl group (CC(C)CC) adds steric bulk and increases the molecular weight, which can raise the melting point, estimated at +20°C. 
- The presence of the ether linkage (C-O-C) can have a minor effect on the melting point, estimated at +5°C. 
- The overall molecular structure is complex and includes multiple functional groups that can interact with each other, leading to a higher melting point than a simple benzene ring. 
- The molecule has a high degree of symmetry, which can contribute to a higher melting point due to better packing in the solid state, estimated at +10°C. 
- The molecule has a significant molecular weight, which can increase the melting point due to stronger van der Waals forces, estimated at +15°C. 
- The presence of the nitrogen atoms in the urea and amide groups can also contribute to the melting point through hydrogen bonding and resonance stabilization, estimated at +20°C. 
- The overall predicted melting point is the sum of these contributions.
